message_1: Consider the set S = {1/n | n ∈ N} ∪ {0}. Is S a compact set in the metric space R with the standard metric? If yes, prove it, if no, give a counterexample.
message_2:
Yes, S is a compact set in the metric space R with the standard metric.

Recall that a set is compact if and only if it is closed and bounded. We will show that S is both closed and bounded.

1. Bounded: A set is bounded if there exists a real number M such that for all elements x in the set, |x| ≤ M. In our case, S = {1/n | n ∈ N} ∪ {0}. Clearly, all elements in S are non-negative, and 1/n ≤ 1 for all n ∈ N. Thus, we can choose M = 1, and we have |x| ≤ 1 for all x in S. Therefore, S is bounded.

2. Closed: A set is closed if it contains all its limit points. We will show that S contains all its limit points. First, note that the only possible limit point of the sequence 1/n as n goes to infinity is 0. This is because for any ε > 0, we can find an N ∈ N such that 1/N < ε (by the Archimedean property of real numbers). Then, for all n ≥ N, we have |1/n - 0| = 1/n < ε, which means that 0 is a limit point of the sequence. Since 0 is already in S, S contains this limit point.

Now, we need to show that there are no other limit points. Suppose there exists a limit point x ≠ 0. Then, there exists a subsequence of 1/n that converges to x. However, since the sequence 1/n converges to 0, any subsequence must also converge to 0, which contradicts the assumption that x ≠ 0. Therefore, there are no other limit points, and S is closed.

Since S is both closed and bounded, it is compact in the metric space R with the standard metric.
